div.p: As it hath beene Acted with good Applause at the private house in Drury Lane, her Majesties Servants.
LONDON. Printed by T. C. for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his shop at Furnivalls Jnne Gate in Holbourne. 1639.

list.head: The Actors names.
list.item: GAsper De Vilarezo, an old Count, Father to Sebastiano, Catalina and Berinthia Sebastiano, sonne to Vilarezo.
Antonio a lover of Berinthia, and friend to Sebastiano.
Count de monte nigro, a braggard.
Ansilva, a waiting gentle woman to the two Sister.

div.head: TO THE WORTHILY Honoured, Henry Osborne Esquire.
div.p: TIll J be able to give you a better proofe of my service, let not this oblation be despised. It is a Tragedy which received encouragement and grace on the English Stage; and though it come late to the Impression, it was the second birth in this kinde, which I dedicated to the Scene, as you have Art to distinguish; you have mercy and a smile, if you finde a Poem infirme through want of age, and experience the mother of strength. It is many yeares since I see these papers, which make haste to kisse your hand; if you doe not accuse the boldnesse and pride of them; I will owne the child, and beleeve Tradition so farre, that you will receive no dishonour by the acceptance; I never affected the wayes of flattery: some say I have lost my preferment, by not practising that Court sinne; but if you dare beleeve, I much honour you, nor is it upon guesse, but the taste and knowledge of your abilitie and merit; and while the Court wherein you live, is fruitfull with Testimonies of your mind, my Character is seal'd up, when I have said that your vertue hath taken up a faire lodging. Read when you have leasure, and let the Author be fortunate to be knowne

div.head: A Catalogue of such things as hath beene Published by James Shirley Gent.

list.item: Changes, or Love in a Maze.

div.head: Actus. 1. Scaena 1.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: THe noble curtesies I have received
At Lisbone worthy friend, so much engage me
That I must dye endebted to your worth,
Vnlesse you mean to accept what I've studied.
Although but partly to discharge the summe.
Due to your honour'd love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now Sebastiano will you forfeit
The name of friend then I did hope our love
Had outgrowne complement.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I speake my thoughts,
My tongue and heart are relatives, I thinke
I have deserved no base opinion from you;
I wish not onely to perpetuate
Our friendship, but to exchange that common name
Of friend, for

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What? take heede, do not prophane;
Wouldst thou be more then friend? It is a name,
Vertue can onely answer to, couldst thou
Vnite into one, all goodnesse whatsoe're
Mortality can boast of, thou shalt finde,.
The circle narrow bounded to containe
This swelling treasure; every good admits
Degrees, but this being so good it cannot:
For he's no friend is not superlative,
Indulgent parents, brethren, kindred, tied
By the naturall flow of blood; alliances,
And what you can imagine, is to light,
To weigh with name of friend: they execute
At best, but what a nature prompts e'm to,
Are often lesse then friends, when they remaine
our kinsmen still, but friend is never lost.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay then Antonio you mistake, I meane not
To leave of friend, which with another title
Would not be lost, come them Ile tell you Sir,
I would be friend and brother, thus our friendship
Shall like a diamond set in gold not loose
His sparkling, but shew fairer; I have a paire
Of sisters, which I would commend, but that
I might seeme partiall their birth and fortunes
Deserving noble love; if thou beest free
From other faire ingagement, I would be proud
To speake them worthy, come shalt go and see them:
I would not beg them sutors, fame hath spred
Through Portugall their persons, and drawne to Avero.
Many affectionate gallants.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Catalina and Berinthia

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Report speakes loud their beauties, and no less
Vertue in either well, I see you strive
To leave no merrit where you meane to honour,
I cannot otherwise escape the censure
Of one ingratefull, but by waiting on you
Home to Avero

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You shall honour me,
And glad my noble Father, to whom you are
No stranger, your owne worth before, hath beene
Sufficient preparation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha?
I have not so much choise Sebastiane,
But if one Sister of Antonios,
May have a commendation to your thoughts,
I will not spend much Art in praysing her,
Her vertue speake it selfe, I shall be happy,
And be confirmd you brother, though I misse
Acceptance at Avero.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Still you out doe me, I could never wish
My service better plac'd, at opertunity
Ile visit you at Eluas, i'th meane time
Lets hast to Avero, where with you Ile bring
My double welcome, and not faile to second
Any designe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You shall teach me a lesson
Against we meete at Eluas Castle sit.

div.stage: Enter Gaspar de Vilarezo, and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What gallants sirra are they newly entred?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Count de Monte Nigro my Lord, and Don Valasco,

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Give your observance then, I know their businesse;
Catalina and Berinthia are the starrs
Direct them hither, Gaspars house shall give
Respect to all, but they are two such Iewels,
I must dispose maturely, I should else
Returne ingratitude upon the heavens
For leaving me such pledges, not am I,
Like other fathers carried with the streame
Of love toth youngest, as they were in birth
They had my tendernesse, Catalina then
Is eldest in my care, Berinthia
Her childs part too, both faire and vertuous;
But daughters are held losses to a family,
Sonnes onely to maintaine honour and stemme
Alive in their posterity, and I now thinke on't,
My sonne Sebastiano hath beene slow
In his returne from Lisbone, oh that boy
Renewes my age with hope, and hath returnd
My care in education, weight for weight
With noble quality, will belov'd byth best
O th Dons in Spaine and Portugall, whose loves
Do often threten his absence to such length
As this hath beene.
sp.stage: Enter Count de monte Nigro, and Catalina.
sp.l: But Here's my eldest daughter
With her amorous Count, Ile not be seene,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: You have beene absent long my noble Count,
beshrew me but I dreamt on you last night.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ha ha, did you so, I tickle her in her sleep I perceive;
Sweete Lady I did but like the valiant beast,
Give a little ground, to returne with a greater
Force of love, now by my fathers sword
And gauntlet thart a pretious peece of vertue,
But prethee what didst dreame of me last night?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Nay twas an idle dreame, not worth the repitition,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Thou dreamst I warrant thee, that I was fighting
For thee up to the knees in blood, why I dare doo't,
Such dreames are common with Count de monte
Nigro, my sleepes are nothing else but rehearsals of
Battels and wounds and ambuscadoes, Donzell Delphebo
Was a Mountebank of vallour, Rosicbeere a puffe;
My dreames deserve to be ith Chronicles,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Why, now my dreame is out,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I dreamt that you were fighting.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: And that in single combate, for my sake
You slew a giant, and you no sooner had
Rescued my honour, but there crept a pigmee
Out of the earth, and kild you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Very likely, the valliantst man must dye,

sp.speaker: Cata,
sp.l: What by a pigmee?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I, thats another giant, I remember Hercules
Had a conflict with'em, oh my Dona
Catalina I well would I were so happy once to
Maintaine some honourable duell for thy sake, I shall
Nere be well, till I have kild some body; fight, tis true
I have never yet flesht my selfe in blood, no body
Would quarell with me, but I finde my spirit prompt
If occasion would but winke at me, why not? wherefore has
Nature given me these brawny armes, this manly bulke,
And these Collossian supporters nothing but to sling
The sledge, or pitch the bare, and play with
Axletrees; if thou lovest me, do but command me
Some worthy service; pox a dangers I weigh 'em no
More than fleabitings, would some body did hate that
Face, now I wish it with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Would you have any body hate me?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Yes, Ide hate 'em, Ide but thrust my hand into their
Mouth downe to the bottome of their bellies, plucke
Out their lungs and shake their insides outward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Noble Sir, you neede not heape more protestations,
I do beleeve you love me,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe you beleeve I love, and not accept it?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes I accept it too, but apprehend me
As men doe guifts, whose acceptation does not
Binde to performe what every giver craves;
Without a staine to virgin modesty
I can accept your love, but pardon me,
It is beyond my power to grant your suite.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh you too much subject a naturall guift,
And make your selfe beholding for your owne:
The Sunne hath not more right to his owne beames,
With which he gildes the day, nor the Sea lord
Of his owne waues.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Alasse, what ist to owne a passion
Without power to direct it, for I move,
Not by a motion I can call my owne,
But by a higher rapture, in obedience
To a father, and I have yet no freedome
To place affection, so you but endeere me
Without a merit.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Here my sister.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: And Don Valasco, how now, are thy arrowes feathred?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well enough for roving.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Roving I thought to.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I hope faire.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Shoote home then; Valasco I have
Presented my miseris with a paper of verses, see she
Is reading of 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Didst make em thy selfe

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: My money did, what an idle question is that? as tho we
That are great men, are not furnished with stipendary
Muses, am sure for my owne part I can buy 'em
Cheaper than I can make 'em a great deale, would
You have learning have no reward, she laughs
At 'em, I am glad of that.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: They savour of a true Poeticke fury.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Do you smell nothing, something hath some savour.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: But this line my thinks hath more more feete than the rest.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: It sho'd run the better for that Lady, I did it a purpose.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: But heres another lame.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That was my conceit, my owne invention, lame
Halting verses, there's the greatest Art, besides I
Thereby give you to understand, that I am valiant,
Dare cut of legs and armes at all times and make 'em
Goe halting home that are my enemies, I am
An ●ambographier now it is out.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: For honours sake what's that?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: One of the sourest versifiers that ever crept out of
Pernassus when I set on't. I can make any body hang himselfe
With pure Iambicks, I can fetch blood with Asclepiads
Sting, with Phalenciums whip, with Saphicks Bastinado, with hexameter and pentameter, and
Yet I have a trimeter left for thee my Dona Catalina

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Conclude a peace sir with your passion.
I am sory love hath beene unkind to you.
To point at me, who, till the first have knit
The sacred knot of marriage am forbid
To thinke of love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I cannot desist,
I am in love with every thing you say,
This your deniall as it comes from you
Bids me still love you, pardon faire Berinthia,
Valasco hath not power to rule himselfe;
Be you lesse faire, or vertuous, perhaps
I may abate my service.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Old Gaspars house is honourd by such guests,
Now by the tombe of my progenitors,
I envied, that your fame should visit me
So oft without your person, Sebestiano
Hath beene long happy in your noble friendship,
And cannot but improve himselfe in vertues,
That lives so neere your love.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Don Antonio de Riviero.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: With whose noble worth
You oft have fill'd discourse, thought your selfe happy
In his choyce friendship; if his body cary
So many graces, it is heaven within,
Where his soule is.

sp.speaker: Vila,
sp.l: Sebastiano, thou hast largely recompene'd
Thy tedious absence, you shall dishonour me,
Vnlesse you thinke your selfe as welcome here,
As at your Eluas Castle, Vilarezo
Was once as you are sprightly, and though I say it
Maintained my fathers reputation,
And honour of our house with actions
Worthy our name and family, but now,
Time hath let fall cold snow upon my haires,
Ploughed on my browes the furrowes of his anger
Disfurnishd me of active blood, and wrapt me
Halfe in my seare cloth, yet I have minde
That bids me honour vertue, where I see it
Bud forth and spring so hopefully,

sp.speaker: Anto,
sp.l: You speake all noblenesse, and encourage me
To spend the greenenesse of my rising yeares
So to thadvantage, that at last I may
Be old like you.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Daughters speake his welcome, Catalina.

sp.speaker: Cata
sp.l: Sir, you are most welcome.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Howe's that? she sayes he is most welcome, he were
Not best love her, she never made me such a reverence
For all the kisses I have bestowed upon her since
I first opened my affection, I do not like this
Follow, I mus be faire to use doctor Sharkins cunning,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It were not truely noble to affront him;
My blood boyles in me, it shall I coole againe,
The place is venerable by her presence,
And I may be deceiv'd, Valasco then
Keepe distance with thy feares.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: How now Antonio, where hast thou lost thy selfe?
Strucke dead with Ladies eyes? I could star-gaze
For ever thus, oh pardon love, gainst whom
I often have prophan'd, and mockd thy fires,
Thy flames now punish me, let me collect:
They are both excellent creatures, there is
A Majestie in Catalinas eye, and every part carries ambition
Or Queene upon it, yet Berinthia
Hath something more than all this praise, though she
Command the world, this hath more power ore me;
Here I have lost my freedome, not the Queene
Of love could thus have wounded poore Antonio:
Ile speake to her; Lady I'm an Novice, yet in love.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: She jests at me, yet I should be proud to be
Your servant.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I entertaine no servants that are proud.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Divine Berinthia!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: She checks my rudenesse that so openly
I seeme to court her, and in presence too
Of some that have engaged themselves perhaps
To her already.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Come let us in, my house spreads to receive you,
Which you may call your owne, Ile leade the way.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Please you walke Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It will become me thus to waite on you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Does not the foole ride us both?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What foole? both, whom?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That foole, both us, we are but horses and may
Walke one another for ought I see before the doore, when he
Is alight and entred, I do not relish that same
Novice, he were not best gull me; harke you Don
Valasco, what shals doe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe, why?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: This Antonio is a sutor to one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I feare him not.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: I do not feare him neither, I dare fight with him, and
He were ten Antonios, but the Ladies Don, the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Berinthia, to whom
I pay my love devotions, in my eare
Seemd not to welcome him, your Lady did.

sp.speaker: Coant.
sp.l: I but for all that he had most mind to your mistris,
And I do not see but if he pursue it,
There is a possibility to scale the fort, Ladies
Mindes may alter, by your favour, I have lesse
Cause to feare o'th two; if he love not Catalina
My game is free, and I may have a course in
Her Parke the more easily.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tis true, he preferred service to Berinthia,
And what is she then to resist the vowes
Antonio if he love, dare heape upon her?
He's gracious with her father, and a friend
Deere as his bosome to Sebastiano,
And may be is directed by that brother
To aime at her, or if he make free choyce,
Berinthias beauty will draw up his soule.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: And yet now I thinke on't, he was very sawcey
With my love to support her arme, which she
Accepted too familiarly, and she should
But love him, it were as bad for me, for tho he care
Not for her, I am sure she will never abide me after it,
By this hilts I must kill him, theres no remedy,
I cannot helpe it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile know my destiny.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: And I my fate but here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The strangest resolution of a father
I ever heard, I was covetous
To acquaint him with my wishes, praid his leave
I might be servant to Berinthia,
But thus he briefly answered, untill
His eldest daughter were dispos'd in marriage
His youngest must not love, and therefore wisht me
Vnlesse I could place Catalina here,
Leave off soliciting, yet I was welcome,
you fed on nothing but Berinthia,
From whose faire eyes love threw a thousand flames
into Antonios heart, her cheeks bewraying
As many amorous blushings, which brake out
Like a forc'd lightning from a troubled cloud,
Discovering a restraint, as if within
She were at conflict, which her colour onely
Tooke liberty to speake, but soone fell backe,
And as it were checkt by silence.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Ile stay no longer, sir a word with you, are you desperat?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Desperate, why sit?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I aske and you be desperate, are you weary of your
Life, and you be, say but the word; some body can tell
How to dispatch you without a physitian, at a minuits warning.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: You are the noble Count de monte Nigro.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I care not a Spanish fig what you count me, I must
Call you to account sir; in briefe the Lady
Dona Catalina is my mistris, I do not meane to be baffled
While this toole has any steele in't, and I have some
Mettall in my selfe too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Dona Catalina? do you love her?
She is a Lady in whom onely lives
Natures and Arts perfection, borne to shame
All former beauties, and to be the wonder
Of all succeeding, which shall fade and wither
When she is but remembred.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I can endure no more, Diablo, he is mortally in love
With Catalina.

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: Tis so, he's tane with Catalinaes beautie.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Sir I am a servant of that Lady, therefore eate up
Your words, or you shall be sensible that I am Count
De monte Nigro, and she's no dish for Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir I will do you right.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Or I will right my selfe.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: He did direct those prayses unto me
This doth confirme it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He cannot so soone alter,
I shall discover a passion through my eyē.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Thou shewest thy selfe a noble Gentleman, the
Count is now thy friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Does it become me sir, to prosecute
Where such a noble Count is interessed,
Vpon my soule I wish the Lady yours,
Here my suite fals, with tender of my servicē;
Would you were married, nay in bed together
My honourable Count.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Your face is cloudy sir, as you suspected
Your presence were not welcome; had you naught
But title of a brothers friendship, it were
Enough to oblige us to you, but your worth
In Catalinaes eies, bids me proclaime you
A double acceptation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh you are bounteous Ladie.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Sir—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe not feare me,
I am not worthie your opinion,
It shall be happinesse for me to kisse
This Ivory hand,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: The whilst I kisse her lip and be immotall.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio my father is a rocke,
In that he first resolved, and I account it part of my
Owne unhappinesse, I hope you hold me not suspected,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I were unworthy such a friend, his care
Becomes him nobly; has not younder Count
Some hope of Catalina.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My father thinkes that sister worthy of
More than a bare Nobility.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile backe to Eluas noble sir,
This entertainement is so much above
Antonios merit, if I leave you not
I shall be out of hope to—

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Nay then you mocke me sir, you must not leave me
Without discourtesie so soone, we triffle time,
This night you are my guest, my honored Count,
My Don Valasco.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, wee'le follow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha I am resolv'd, like Barge-men when they row.
Ile looke another way then that I goe.

div.head: Actus 2. Scaena I.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Ansilva you observe with curious eye
All Gentlemen that come hither, whats your opinion.
Of Don Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My opinion Madam, I want Art.
To judge of him.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Then without Art your judgement.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He is one of the most accomplisht Gentlemen
Ansilva ere beheld, pardon Madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Nay, it doth not displease, 'yare not alone,
He hath friends to second you, and who dost thinke
Is cause he tarries here.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Your noble father will not let him goe.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: And canst thou see no higher? then thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam, I guesse at something more.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Love?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Of whom?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I know not that.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: How not that? thou'dst bring thy former truth
Into suspition, why tis more apparant
Then that he loves.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: If judging eyes may guide him,
I know where he should 'chuse, but I have heard
That love is blind.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Vertue would direct him Madam unto you, I know not his
Obedience, I shall repent if I offend.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.p: Tha'rt honest, be yet more free, hide not a thought that may concerne it.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Then Madam I thinke he loves my Lady Berinthia;
I have observ'd his eyes rowle that way,
Even now I spied him
Close with her in the Arbour, pardon me Madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Th'ast done me faithfull service, be yet more vigilant,
I know thou speakst all truth, I doe suspect him,
My sister, ha? Dare shee maintaine contention?
Is this the dutie bindes her to obey
A fathers precepts, tis dishonour to me.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam, heres a pretty hansome stripling new alight,
Enquires for Don Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Let me see him, 'twill give me good occasion to be
My owne observer;
Whom would you sir?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I am sent in quest of Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: He speakes like a Knight errant, he comes in quest,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I have heard it a little vertue in some Spanniels to
Quest now and then Lady.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: But you are none.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My Mr. cannot beate me from him Madam, I am one of
The oldest appurtenances belonging to him, and yet I
Have little mosse in my chinne.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: The more to come, a wittie knave.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: No more wit then will keep my head warme, I beseech you amiable Virgin help my Master Antonio to some intelligence that a servant of his waits to speake with him from his sister Madona Castabella.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: It shall not neede sir, Ile give him notice my selfe,
Ansilva Entertaine time with him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: A promising young man.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Doe you waite on this Lady?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Wee are both of a tribe then, though wēe differ in our sexe, I beseech you taxe me not of immodesty, or want of breeding, that I did not salute you upon the first view of your person, this kisse be as good as presse-mony to bind me to your service.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: 'Yare very welcome, by my virginity.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Your virginitie a good word to save an oath, for all she made me a cursie, it was not good manners to leave mee so soone 'yare very welcome by my virginity; was she afraid of breaking, it may be she is crack'd already, but here she is againe.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: May I begge your name sir?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: No begger sweet, would you have it at length, then
My name is Signior Baltazaro Clere Mautado,
But for brevities sake they call me Diego.

sp.speaker: Ans,
sp.l: Then Signior Diego once more you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Bazelez manes Signiora, and what my tongue is not able to expresse, my head shall; it seemes you have liv'd long a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Not above seven or eight and thirty yeares.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: By Lady a tried Virgin, you have given the world
A large testimony of your virginity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I should be thus a disobedient daughter
A Fathers Hests are sacred.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But in love
They have no power, it is but tyranny,
Plaine usurpation to command the minde
Against its owne election; I am yours,
Vow'd yours for ever, send me not away
Shipwrack'd ith' habour, say but you can love me,
And I will waite an age, not wish to move
But by commission from you, to whom
I render the possession of my selfe:
Ha? we are betrai'd, I must use cunning,
She lives in you, and take not in worse sence;
You are more gracious, in that you are
So like your eldest sister, in whom lives
The coppy of so much perfection,
All other seemē to imitate.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Does he not praise me now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But here she is,
Madam, not finding you ith' garden,
I met this Lady.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I came to tell you
A servant of yours attends with letters from
Your sister Madona Castabella.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Diego what newes?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady remembers her love, these letters informe you the state of all things.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.p: What serious conference had you sister with that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Would you had heard them sister, they concern'd your Commendations.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Why should he not deliver them to my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It may be then
You would have thought he flattered.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I like not this rebound,
Tis fairest to catch at fall.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sister, I hope
You have no suspition, I have courted
His stay or language on my life no accent
Fell from me, your owne eare would not have heard
With acceptation.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: It may be so, and yet I dare acquit you,
In duty to a Father, you would wish me
All due respect, I know it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You observe the waiting creatures in the blacke,
Harke, you apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: With as much tenacity as a servant.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I hope sir, now we shall enjoy you longer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The gods would sonner be sicke with Nectar, than Antoni Antonio
Grow weary of such faire societie;
But I am at home expected, a poore sister,
My fathers care alive, and dying was
His Legacy, having out-staid my time
Is tender of my absence.

div.stage: Enter Vilarezo, Sebastiano, Count, and Valasco.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: My Lord Antonio meanes to take his leave.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Although last night you were inclin'd to goe,
Let us prevaile this morning.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: A servant of his, he saies, brought letters
To hasten departure.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Why sirra, will you rob us of your master.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Not guilty my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Sir, if you'le needs go, we'le bring you on your way.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I humbly thank your honour, Ile not be so trouble some.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Would you were gone once, I doe not meane to trouble my selfe so much I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have now a charge upon me, I hope it may
Excuse me, if I hasten my returne.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: Tis faire, and reasonable, well sir, my sonne
Shall waite on you oth' way, if any occasion
Draw you to Avero, lets hope you'le see us,
You know your welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Lord the favours done me, would proclaime
I were too much unworthy not to visit you,
Oft as I see Avero; Madam I part with some unhappinesse
To lose your presence, give me leave I may
Be absent your admirer, to whose memory
I write my selfe a servant,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Poxe on your complemênt, you were not best write
In her table-bookes.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: You doe not know
What power you have o're me, that but to please you
Can frame my selfe to take a leave so soone.

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: What thinke you of that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Why, she sayes she has power to take her leave
So soone, no hurt ath' world in't, I hope she is an
Innocent Lady.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The shallow rivers glide away with noise,
The deepe are silent, fare you well Lady.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I told you he is a shallow fellow.

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: I know not what to thinke on't Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gentlemen happinesse and successe in your desires.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ile see you a league or two.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: By any meanes, nay sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My Lord I have a suite to you before I goe.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: To me Diego, prethee speake it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: That while other Gentlemen are happy to devide their affections among the Ladies, I may have your honours leave to beare some good-will to this Virgin: Cupid hath throwne a dart at me, like a blinde buzzard as he was, and theres no recovery without a cooler; if I be sent into these parts, I desire humbly I may be bould to rub acquaintance with Mistresse Ansilva.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: With all my heart Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Madam, I hope you will not be an enemy to a poore
Flye that is taken in the flame of the blind god.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: You shall have my consent sir.

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: But what say a Ansilva, hast thou a mind to a husband?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: I feare I am too young seven yeares hence were time enough for me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Shees not full fortie yet sir.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I honour the Antiquitie of her maidenhead, thou
Mistresse of my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come lets away Diego our horses—

sp.speaker: Vila.
sp.l: We'le bring you to the game.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Yes, wee'le bring him out of doores, would wee
were shut of him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Hay ho, who would have thought I should have benne in love with a stripling, have I seene so many maiden-heades suffer before me, and must mine come to the blocke at fortie yeares old, if this Diego have the grace to come on, I shall have no power to keepe my selfe chast any longer; how many maides have beene overrunne with this love? but Here's my Lady.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Sir, you love my sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With an obedient heart.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Where do you think Don Antonio hath made choice
To place his love?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There where I wish it may grow older in desire,
And be crown'd with fruitfull happinesse.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Hath your affection had no deeper roote,
That tis rent up already, I had thought
It would have stood a Winter, but J see
A Summer storme hath kil'd it, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How's this, a Summers storme!
Lady by the honour of your birth,
Put off these cloudes, you maze me, take off
The wonder you have put upon Valasco,
And solve these riddles.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: You love Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With a devoted heart, else may I die
Contempt of all mankinde, not my owne soule
Is deerer to me.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: And yet you wish Antonio may be crown'd
With happinesse in his love, he loves Birinthia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Beyond expression, to see how a good nature
Free from dishonour in it selfe, is backward
To thinke another guilty, suffers it selfe
Be poisoned with opinion, did your eyes
Emptie their beames so much in admiration
Of your Berinthias beauty, you left none
To observe your owne abuses,

sp.speaker: Vala.
sp.l: Doth not Antonio dedicate his thoughts
To your acceptance, 'tis impossible,
I heard him praise you to the heavens, above 'em;
Made himselfe hoarse but to repeate your vertues
As he had beene in extasie; love Birinthia?
Hell is not blacker than his soule, if he
Love any goodnesse but your selfe.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: That lesson he with impudence hath reade
To my owne eares, but shall I tell you sir?
We are both made but properties to raise
Him to his partiall ends, flattery is
The stalkeing horse of pollicy, saw you not,
How many flames he shot into her eyes
When they were parting, for which she pay'd backe
Her subtill teares, he wrung her by the hand,
Seem'd with the greatnesse of his passion
To have beene o're borne, Oh cunning treachery!
Worthy our justice, true be commended me;
But could you see the Fountaine that sent forth
So many cozening streames, you would say Styx
Were Christ all to it, and wast not to the Count,
Whom he suppos'd was in pursuite of me;
Nay, whom he knew did love me, that he might
Fire him the more to consummate my marriage
That I disposed he might have of accesse
To his belov'd Berinthia, the end
Of his desires I can confirme it, he praid
To be so happy with my fathers leave
To be her amorous servant, which he nobly
Denied, partly expressing your engagements;
If you have least suspition of this truth:
Butdee' thinke she love you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot challenge her, but she has let fall
Something to make me hope, how thinke you shee's
Affected to Antonio?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: May be
Luke warme as yet, but soone as as shees caught,
Inevitably his, without prevention.
For my owne part I hate him in whom lives
A will to wrong a Gentleman, for hee was
Acquainted with your love, 'twas my respect
To tender so your injury, I could not
Be silent in it. what you meane to doe
I leave to your owne thoughts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh stay sweete Lady, leave me not to struggle
Alone with this universall affliction;
You speake even now Berinthia would be his
Without prevention, oh that Antidote,
That Balsome to my wound.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Alas I pitty you, and the more, because
I see your troubles so amaze your judgement,
Ile tell you my opinion sir oth' sudden;
For him, he is not worth Valasco's anger;
Onely thus, you shall discover to my Father,
She promis'd you her love, be confident
To say you did exchange faith to her; this alone
May chance assure her, and if not I hav't:
Steale her away, your love I see is honourable,
So much I suffer when desert is wounded,
You shall have my assistance, you apprehend me,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am devoted yours, command me ever.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Keepe smooth your face, and still maintaine your worship
With Berinthia, things must be manag'd
And strucke in the maturity, noble sir; J wish
You onely fortunate in Berinthias love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Words are too poore to thanke you, I looke on you
As my safe guiding starre.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: But I shall prove a wandering starre, I have
A course which I must finish for my selfe.
Glide on thou subtill mover, thou hast brought
This instrument already for thy aymes,
Sister, Ile breake a Serpents egge betimes,
And teare Antonio from thy very bosome,
Love is above all law of nature, blood,
Not what men call, but what that bides is good.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Be not so carefull Cooze, your brothers well.
Be confident if he were otherwise
You should have notice, whom hath he to share
Fortunes without you? all his ills are made
Lesse by your bearing part, his good is doubled
By your communichaing.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: By this reason
All is not well, in that my ignorance
What fate hath hapned, barres me off the portion
Belongs to me sister, but my care
Is so much greater, in that Diego whom
J charg'd to put on wings, if all were well,
Is dull in his returne.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: His Master happily hath commanded him
To attend him homewards, this is recompenc'd
Already, looke they are come;
Y'are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh sister, ere you let fall words of welcome,
Let me unlade a treasure in your eare
Able to weigh downe man.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What treasure brother, you amaze me,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Never was man so blest,
As heavens had studied to enrich me here,
So am I fortunate.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You make me covetous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have a friend.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You have a thousand sir, is this your treasure?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But I have one more worth then millions,
And he doth onely keepe alive that name
Of friendship in his breast, pardon Villandras,
Tis not to straine your love, whom I have tried,
My worthiest cozen.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But where is this same friend, why came he not
To Eluas with you, sure he cannot be
Deare to you Brother, to whom I am not indebted
At least for you.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I have many deare friends too, my Taylor is one
To whom I am indebted

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: His Commission
Stretch'd not so farre, a Fathers tie was on him,
But I have his noble promise, er't be long,
We shall enjoy him.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Brother I hope
You know how willingly I can entertaine
Your blisse, and make it mine, pray speake the man
To whom we owe so much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Twere not charity to starve you thus with shaddowes,
Take him and with him in thy bosome locke
The Mirrour of fidelity, Don Sebastiano.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I oft have heard you name him full of worth,
And upon that relation have laid up,
One deare to my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But he must be dearer Castabella, harke you sister,
I have beene bold upon thy vertue, to
Invite him to you, if your heart be free.
Let it be empty ever, if he doe not
Fill it with noblest love, to make relation,
What zeale he gave of a worthy nature,
At our last parting (when betwixt a sonne,
And friend he so divided his affections
And out did both) you would admire him: were
I able I would build a temple where
We tooke our leave,
The ground it selfe was hallowed
So much with his owne piety, Diego saw it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes sir, I saw, heard, and wondred.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come I will tell you all, to your chamber sister,
Diego our plot must on, all time is lost
Vntill we try the mooving.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: If the plot please you sir, let me alone to play my part
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come Castabella, and prepare to heare
A story not of length but worthy your eare.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You have not dealt so honourably sir,
As did become you, to proceede so farre
Without my knowledge, give me leave to tell you
You are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord I am sorry,
If I have any way trangrest, I was not
Respectlesse of your honour, nor my fame,
Valasco shall be unhappy, if by him
You shall derive a staine, my actions faire,
I have done nothing with Berinthia,
To merit such a language, twas not ripe,
For me to interrupt the father, when I knew not
What grace I hold with her.

sp.speaker: Vil,
sp.l: Hell on her grace, is this her duty? ha,
I can forget my nature if she dare
Make so soone forfeit of her piety;
Oh where is that same awfull dread of Parent,
Should live in children; tis her ambition
To out runne her sister, but Ile curbe her impudence,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Retire your selfe, this passion must have way,
This workes as I would have it, feare nothing sir,
Obscure.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Ile cloyster her, and starve this spirit
Makes her deceive my trust; Catalina
Vpon thy duty I command thee, take
Her custody on thee, keepe her from the eye
Of all that come to Averro, let her discourse
With pictures on the wall, I feare she hath
Forgot to say her prayers, is she growne sensuall?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: But my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Oh keepe thy accents for a better cause,
She hath contemd us both, thou caust not see
What blemish she derives unto our name.
Yet these are sparkes, he hath a fire within,
Will turne all into flames, wheres Valasco?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Good sir, a much afflicted worthy Gentleman,
At your displeasure.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Thou art too full of pitty, nay th'art cruell
To thy owne fame, he must not have accesse
To prosecute, it was my doting sinne,
Of too much confidence in Berinthia,
Gave her such libertie, on my blessing punish it,
Twill be a vertuous act, the snow I thought
Was not more innocent, more cold, more chaste
Why my command bound her in ribs of ice,
But shees dissolv'd, to thee Ile leave her now,
Be the maintainer of thy Fathers vow,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why I am undone now,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Nothing lesse, this conflict
Prepares your peace, I am her guardian,
Love smiles upon you, I am not inconstant,
Having more power to assist you, but away,
We must not be discri'd, expect ere long
To heere what you desire.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My blisse I remember.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Berinthia, y'are my prisoner, at my leisure
Ile studdy on your fate, I cannot be
Friend to my selfe, when I am kind to thee.

div.head: Actus. 3. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Sebastiano, Berinthia, Ansilva, Diego meetes them.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: WElcome honest Diego, your Master Antonio is in health I hope.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: He commanded me, remember his service to you, I have obtaind his leave for a small absence to perfect a suite I lately commenc'd in this Court.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You follow it close me thinks Berinthia, I see this cloud
Vanish already, be not dejected, soone
Ile know the depth ont, should the world forsake thee,
Thou shalt not want a brother deere Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: This is my Lady Berinthia, prethee let me shew
Some manners, Madam my Master Antonio speakes his
Service to you in this paper: alas Madam, I was but
Halfe at home, and I am returnd to see if I can recover
The tother peece of my selfe, so, was it not a reasonable
Complement.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Antonio, he's constant J perceive.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: So, we are alone, sweet Mistresse Ansilva, J am bold
To renue my suite, which least it should either
Fall or depend too long having past my declaration,
I shall desire to come to a judgement.
My cause craves nothing but justice,
That is, that you would be mine; and now since
You selfe is judge also, I beseech you be not partiall
In your owne cause, but give seatence for the plaintiffe, and
I will discharge the fees of the Court on this fashion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here is a haven yet to rest my soule on,
In midst of all unhappinesse, which I looke on,
With the same comfort a distressed Sea man
A farre off, viewes the coast he would enjoy,
When yet the Seas doe tosse his reeling barke,
Twixt hope and danger, thou shalt be conceald.

div.stage: She mistaking as she moved put up the Letter, it fals downe.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Here's my Lady Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: What care I for my Lady Berinthia, and she thinkes
Much, would she had one to stopp her mouth.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: But I must observe her, upon her fathers displeasure,
She is committed to my Ladies custody, who hath made
Me her keeper, she must be lockt up.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ha lockt up.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Madam, it is now time you would retire to your owne Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes, prethee doe Ansilva in this gallery,
I breathe but too much aire, oh Diego youle have
An answer I perceive, ere you returne.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: My journey were to no purpose else Madam, I apprehend her. Ile waite an opportunity, alas poore lady, is my sweete heart become a jaylor, there's hope of an office without money.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p:
Diego I spy my Lady Catalina comming this way, pray shrowd your selfe behinde this cloth, I would be loath shee
should ice us here together, quickely, I heare her treading,

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Ansilva.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Who's with you?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: No body Madam.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Was not Diego with you, Antonioes man?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He went from me Madam halfe an houre agoe,
To visit friends ith' City.

sp.speaker: Caf.
sp.l: He hath not seene Berinthia I hope.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Vnlesse he can pierce stone walls Madam, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Direct Don Valasco hither by the backe staires,
I expect him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I shall Madam.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Ha, what's this? a Letter to Berinthia, from whom
Subscrib'd? Antonio, what devill brought this hither?
Furies torment me not, ha, while I am Antonio, expect
Not I can be other then thy servant, all my thoughts
Are made sacred with thy remembrance, whose hope
Sustaines my life, oh I drink poyson from these fatall accents,
Be thy soule blacker then the inke that staines
The cursed paper, would each droppe had falne
From both your hearts, and every Character
Beene texed with blood, I would have tir'd mine eyes
To have read you both dead here, upon my life
Diego hath beene the cunning Mercury
In this conveyance, J suspect his love
Is but a property to advance this suite.
But I will crosse um all;
Don Valasco, you are seasonably arriv'd,
I have a Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For me?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: It does concerne you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: How doe you like it sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As I should a Punyard sticking here, how came
You by it?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I found it here by accident oth' ground,
I am sure it did not grow there, I suppose
Diego, the servant of Antonio
Who colourably pretends affection
To Ansilva, brought it, hees the agent for him.
Now the designe appeares, day is not more conspicuous
Then this cunning.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am resolv'd,

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Antonio or I must change our ayre,
This is beyond my patience, sleepe in this
And never wake to honour, oh my fates,
He takes the freehold of my soule away,
Berinthia, and it, are but one creature,
I have beene a tame foole all this while,
Swallowed my poyson in a fruitelesse hope,
But my revenge, as heavy as Ioves wrath,
Wrapt in a thunderbolt is falling on him,

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Now you appeare all noblenesse, but collect
Draw up your passions to a narrow point
Of vengeance, like a burning glasse that fires
Surest ith smallest beame, he that would kill,
Spends not his idle fury to make wounds,
Farre from the heart of him he fights withall,
Looke where you most can danger, let his head
Bleed out his braines, or eyes, aime at that part
Is deerest to him, this once put to hazzard,
The rest will bleed to death.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Apply this Madam.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: The time invites to action, ile be briefe,
Strike him through Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Mistake me not, I am her sister,
Shee is his heart, make her your owne, you have
A double victory, thus you may kill him
With most revenge, and give your owne desires,
A most confirm'd possession, fighting with him,
Can be no conquest to you, if you meane
To strike him dead, pursue Berinthia,
And kill him with the wounds he made at you,
It will appeare but justice, all this is
Within your fathom sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tis some divinity hangs on your tongue.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: If you consent Berinthia shall not see,
More sunnes till you enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How deere Madam.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Thus, you shall steale her away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh when'

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Provide
Such trusty friends, but let it not be knowne
Vpon your honour, I assist you in't.
And after midnight when soft sleepe hath charm'd
All sences enter the Garden gate.
Which shall to open for you, to know her chamber
A candle shall direct you in the Window,
Ansilva shall attend too, and provide
To give you entrance, thence take Berinthia,
And soone convey her to what place you thinke
Secure and most convenient, in small time
You may procure your owne conditions;
But sir you must engage your selfe to use her
With honourable respects, she is my sister,
Did not I thinke you noble, for the world
I would not runne that hazzard.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let heaven forsake me then, was ever mortall
So bound to womans care, my mothers was
Halfe paid her at my birth, but you have made me
An everlasting debtor.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Select your friend, bethinke you of a place
You may transpose her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am all wings.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: So, when gentle physicke will not serve, we must
Apply more active, but there is
Yet a receipt behind; Valascoes shallow,
And will be planet strucke, to se Berinthia
Dye in his armes: tis so, yet he himselfe
Shall carry the suspition, if art,
Or hell can furnish me with such a poyson,
sleepe thy last sister, whilst thou livest I have,
No quiet in my selfe, my rest thy grave.

div.stage: Diego comes from behinde the hangings.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Goe thy wayes, and the devill wants a breeder thou
Art for him, one spirit and her selfe are able to furnish
Hell and it were unprovided; but I am glad I heard all
I shall love hangings the better while I live:
I perceive some good may be done behind em,
But ile acquaint my Lady Berinthia,
Heres her chamber I observ'd: Madam, Madam
Berinthia,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Whos's there?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Tis I Diego, I am Diego.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Honest Diego, what good newes,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Ya're undone, undone lost, undone for ever; it is time now to be serious.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Wheres my Master Antonioes Letter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here, where, ha, alas, I feare I have lost it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Alas you have undone your selfe, and your sister, my Lady Catalina hath found it, and is mad with rage, and envy against you; I overheard your destruction, she hath shewed it to Don Valasce, and hath plotted that he shall steale you away this night, the doores shall be lest open the houre after twelve.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You amaze me, tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Doe not cast away your selfe, by incredulity, upon my life your fate is cast, nay more, worse then that.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Worse?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: You must be poysoned too, oh shees a cunning devill, and she will carry it so, that Valasco shall bee suspected for your death, what will you doe?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am overcome with amazement?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Madam remember with what noble love my Master Antonio does honour you, and now both save your selfe, and make him happy, how.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am lost man.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Feare not, I will engage my life for your safety,
Seeme not to have knowledge or suspicion, be carefull
What you receive, least you be poysond, leave the
Rest to me, I have a crotchet in my pate shall spoyle
Their musicke, and prevent all danger I warrant you,
By any meanes be smooth, and pleasant, the devils
A knave, your sisters a Traytor, my Master is your noble
Friend, I am your honest servant, and Valasco shall
Shake his eares like an annimall.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It is not to be hoped for.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Then cut of my eares, slit my nose, and make a devill of me, shall I about it say, tis done.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Any thing thou art honest, heaven be neare,
Still to my innocence, I am full of feare.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Spurre cut and away then.

div.stage: Enter Signior Sharkino in his study, furnished with glasses, viols, pictures of wax characters, wands, conjuring habit, Powders paintings, and Scarabeo.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Scarabeo.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Is the doore tongue tide, scrue your selfe halfe out at one of the crevices, and give me notice what patient approathes me.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: I can runne through the key hole sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: This fucus beares
A lively tincture, oh the checke must blush
That weares it, their deceiv'd that say
Art is the ape of nature.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Who ist?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: My Ladies apronstrings, Mistris Ansilva her chamber-maide.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Admit her.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How now raw head and bloody bones, wheres the
Doctor Sharkino? oh here he is.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How does your vertuous Ladie.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: In good health sir.
Wheres the Fucus, and the Powder.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: All is prepared here.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: To see what you can doe, many make legges, and you make faces sir.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
Variety of faces is now in fashion, and all little enough for some to set a good face on't, oh Ladies may now and then commit a slip and have some colour for't, but these are but the outsides of our art, the things we can prescribe to be taken
inwardly, are pretty curiosities, we can prolong life.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: And kill too can you not?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh any that will goe to the price.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: You have poysons I warrant you, how doe they looke, pray lets see one.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh naturall and artificiall, Nessas blood was milke
To em, an extraction of Todes and Vipers, looke
Heres a parcell of Claudius Caesars posset,
Given him by his wife Agrippina here is some of
Hannibals medicine he carried alwaies in the
Pummell of his sword, for a dead lift, a very active
Poyson, which passing the Orifice, kindles
Straite a fire inflames the blood, and makes the marrow
Fly, have you occasion to apply one.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Introth we are troubled with a rat in my Ladies Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: A Rat, give him his bane, would you destroy a City, I have probatinus of Italian Sallets, and our owne Country figs shall doe it rarely, a Rat, I have scarse a poyson so base, the worst is able to kill a man, I have all sorts, from a minute to seven yeares in operation, and leave no markes behinde em, a Rats a Rat.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Pray let me see a remover at twelve houres, and I would be loath to kill the poore thing presently.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Here, you may cast it away upon't, but tis a disparagement to the poyson.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: This will content you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Because it is for a Rat you shall pay no more, my service to my Ladie, my poysons howsoever I give them, variety of operations are all but one. Knockes within .Honest Rats bane in severall-shapes, their vertue is common, and will not be long in killing; you were best looke it be a Rat, Scarabeo.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Sir heres a Gallant enquires for Dector Sharkino

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Vsher him in, it is some Don.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Is your name Signior Sharkino the famous Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: They call me Sharkino.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Doe you not know me?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Your gracious pardon.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I am Count de Monte Nigro.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Your honours sublimity doth illustrate this habitation;
Is there any thing wherein Sharkino may expresse
His humble service? if ought within the circumference
Of a medicinall or Mathematicall science,
May have acceptance with your celsitude,
it shall devolve it selfe.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Devolve it selfe, that word is not in my Table booke; what are all these trinkets?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Take heede I beseech your honour, they are dangerous, this is the devils girdle,

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: A pox oth devill, what have I doe with him,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: It is a dreadfull circle of conjuration, fortified
With sacred characters against the power
Of infernall spirits, within whose round I can tread
Safely, when hell burnes round about me.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Will you see the devill sir?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Ha, the devill? not at this time, I am in some hast,
Any thing but the devill I durst fight with all, harke
You Doctor, letting these things passe, hearing
Of your skill, I am come in my owne person, for
A fragment of your art, harke you, have you any
Receipts to procure love sir?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: All the degrees of it this is ordinary.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Nay I would not have it too strong, the Lady I intend it for, is pretty well taken already, an easing working thing does it.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Here's a powder whose ingrediences were fetchd
From Arabia the happy, a sublimation of the Phoenix
Ashes, when she last burned her selfe, it beares the
Colour of sinamon, two or three souples put into
A cup of wine, fetches up her heart, she can scarce
Keepe it in, for running out of her mouth to you
My noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That, let me have that, Doctor I know tis deare,
Will that gold buy it?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Your honour is bountifull, there needs no circumstance, Minister it by whom you please, your intention binds it to operation.

sp.speaker: Cout.
sp.l: So, so Catalina, I will put your mornings draught
In my pocket— Knocke at the doore
Doctor, I would not be seene.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Please you my Lord obscure your selfe behinde these hangings then, till they be gone, Ile dispatch'em the sooner; or if your honour thinke fit, tis but clouding your person with a simple cloake of mine, and you may at pleasure passe without discovery, my Anotomy shall waite on you.
Prethee come backe yet.
Oh by any meanes goe laynes.
Dost thou thinke it possible that any man can tell where thy things are, but he that stole 'em, hee's but a jugling imposter, a my conscience, come backe againe.

Nay now wee are at furthest, be not rul'd by him, I know he is a cunning man, he told me my fortune once when I was to goe a journey by water, that if I scapt drowning, I should doe well enough, and I have iiv'd ever since.
Well I will try, I am resolv'd; stay, here hee is Pedro, you are acquainted with him, breake the ice, he is alone.

Blesse you Mr. Doctor; sir presuming on your Art, here is a fellow of mine, indeede the Butler, for want of a better; has lost a dozen of Dyaper spoones, and halfe a dozen of silver Napkins yesterday, they were seene by all three of us in the morning betweene sixe and seven set up, and what spirit of the Buttery hath stollen'em before eight, is invisible to our understanding.
He hath delivered you the case right: I beseech you sir doe what you can for a servant, that is like to be in a lamentable case else, heres a gratuity.
Now we shall see what the devill can do, hey, heres one of his spirits I thinke.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
Betweene 7 and 8. the houre; the 1 Luna, the 2 Saturne,
the 3 Iupiter, the 4 Mars, the 5 Sol, the 6 Venus, the 7 Mercury, ha then it was stolne, Mercury is a thiefe, your goods are stolne.

sp.l: Was Mercury the thiefe, pray where dwells he?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Mercury is above the Moone man.
Alas sir tis a great way thither.
Did not I tell you you would be gull'd.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Well y'are a servant, Ile doe something for you; What will you say, if I shew you the man that stole your Spoones and Napkins presently, will that satisfie you.

sp.l: Ile desire no more, oh good Mr. Doctor.
If he does that, ile beleve he has cunning.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Goe to, heares a glasse.
Loe you there now.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Stand your backes North, and stirre not till I bid you;
What see you there?
Heres nothing.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Looke agen, and marke, stand yet more North.
Now I see somebody. 1 And I.

div.stage: The Count comes from behind the Hangings and muffled in a cloake steales of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Marke this fellow muffled in the cloake, he hath stolne your spoones and Napkins, does he not skulke.
'Foote tis strange, he lookes like a theefe, this Doctor I see is cunning.

sp.l: Oh rogue how shall's come by him, oh for an Officer,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yet stirre not,
Oh hees gone, where is he?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Be not too rash, my Art tells me there is danger in't, you must be blinfold all, if you observe me not, all is to no purpose, you must not see till you be forth a doores, shut your eyes, and leade one another, when you are abroad open them and you shall see agen.

sp.l: The thiefe?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: The same, then use your pleasures, so, be sure you see not, conduct them Scarabeo.

div.stage: Enter a Maid with an Vrinall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Oh Mr. Doctor I have got this opportunity to come
to you, but I cannot stay, heres my water, pray sweet Mr. Doctor, tell me, I am in great feare that I have lost—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My maidenhead sir, you can tell by my water.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Dost not thou know?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Oh I doe some what doubt my selfe, for this morning when I rose, I found a paire of breeches on my bed, and I have had a great suspition ever since, it is an evill signe they say, and one does not know what may be in those breeches sometimes; sweets Mr. Doctor, am I a maid still or no, I would be sorry to loose my maiden head ere I were aware, I feare I shall never be honest after it.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Let me see Vrina meretrix; the colour is a strumpet, but the contents deceive not, your maiden head is gone.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And is there no hope to finde it againe?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: You are not every body, by my Art, as in other things that have beene stolne, he that hath stolne your maiden head shall bring it againe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Thanke you sweet Mr. Doctor, I am in your debt for this good newes; oh sweet newes sweet Mr. Doctor.

div.stage: Enter Count beating before him the three Servingmen, they runne in.

sp.l: Cry your honour mercy, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Out you slaves, oh my toes.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What ayles your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Doctor, I am out of breath, where be these wormes crept, I was never so abused since I was swadled: harke you; those 3. Rogues that were here even now, began to lay hold of me, and told me I must give them their Spoones and Napkins; they made a theefe of mee, but I thinke I have made their flesh jelly with kickes and bastinadoes; oh I have no mercy when I set on't, I have made em all poore Iohns, impudent varlets; talke to me of Spoones and Napkins.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Alas one of them was mad, and brought to me to cure him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Nay they were all mad, but I thinke I have madded e'm; I feare J have kickt two or three out of their lives; alas
poore Wretches I am sorry for it now, but I have such an humor of beating & kicking when my footes in once: harke you Doctor, is it not within the compasse of your physicke to take downe a mans courage a thought lower; the truth is, I am apt of myselfe to quarrell upon the least affront ith' world, I cannot be kept in, chaines will not hold me: tother day for a lesse matter than this, I kickt halfe a dozen of high Germans, from one end of the streete to the other, for but offering to shrinke betweene mee and wall; not a day goes o're my head but I hurt some body mortally; poxe a these rogues, I am sorry at my heart I have hurt e'm so, but I can not forbeare.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How? I can scarce forbeare striking you now, for saying it is strange; you would not thinke it: oh the wounds J have given for a very looke; well harke you, if it be not too late, I would be taken downe, but I feare tis impossible, and then every one goes in danger of his life by me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Take downe your spirit, looke you, dee see this inch and a halfe, how tall a man doe you thinke he was? He was twelve cubits high, and three yards compasse at the waste when I tooke him in hand first, ile draw him through a ring ere I have done with him: I keepe him now to breake my poysons, to eate Spiders and Toades, which is the onely dish his heart wishes for; a Capon destroyes him, and the very sight of beefe or mutton makes him sicke; looke, you shall see him eate his supper, come on your wayes, what say you to this Spider? looke how he leapes.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Oh dainty.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Here, saw you that? how many legges now for the hanch of a Toade.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: Twenty, and thanke you sir, oh sweete Toade, oh admirable Toade.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: This is very strange, I nere saw the like, I never knew Spiders and Toades were such good meates before; will he not burst now?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
It shall nere swell him, by to morrow hee shall be an
inch abated, and I can with an other experiment plumpe him and highten him at my pleasure; ile warrant ile take you downe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay but dee here, doe I looke like a Spider-catcher, or Toade-eater.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Farre be it from Shirkino, I have gentle pellets for your Lordship, shall melt in your mouth, 'and take of your valour insensibly; Lozenges that shall comfort your stomacke, and but at a weeke restraine your fury two or three thoughts; does your honour thinke I would forget my selfe, I shew you by this Rat what I can doe by Art: your Lordship shall have an easie composition, no hurt ith' world in't; here take but halfe a dozen of these going to bed, e're morning; it shall worke gently, and in the vertue appeare every day afterward.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But if I find myselfe braking out into fury, I may take e'm often; heres for your pellets of Lozenges, what rare physicke is this? Ile put it in practise presently, farewell Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Happinesse wait on your egregious Lordship, my physicke Shall make your body soluble, but for working on your spirit, beleeve it when you finde it; with any lies we must set forth siour'mples and compositions to utter them: so this is a good dayes worke; leane chaps lay up, and because you have perform'd hamsomly, there is some silver for you, lay up my properties: Tis night already, thus we knaves will thrive, when honest plainnesse know not how to live.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Art sure she has tane it?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: As sure as I am alive? she never eate with
Such an appetite, for I found none left, I would
Be loath to have it so sure in my belly, it will worke
Rarely twelve houres hence.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Thus we worke sure then, time runnes upon
Th' appointed houre, Valasco should rid me of all my
Feares at once, upon thy life be carefull to direct
Him at his first approach, I am sicke till she
Be delivered; be secret as the night, ile to my
Chamber, be very carefull.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, Villandras, Diego, vizzardid and arm'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Art sure thou hast the time right.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.p: Doubt not, yonder's her chamber, the light speakes it; softly.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Whos's there? Vallasco?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: That way, make no noise, things are prepared, softly
So, so, this is good I hope and weight too, my Lady
Berinthia will be sure enough anon, I shall nere
Get more higher, I had much adoe to perswade her
To the spice, but I swore it was a cordiall my Lady
Vs'd her selfe, and poore foole she has swallowed it
Sure.

div.stage: Enter Ant, with Berinthia, Villan, Diego.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam feare not I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Stop her mouth, away.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: So, so, they are gone, alas poore Valasco I pitty thee,
But we creatures of polliticke Ladies must hold the
Same byas with our Mistresses, and tis some pollicy
To make them respect us the better, for feare our
Teeth be not strong enough to keepe in our tongues:
Now must I study out some tale by morning to salute
My old Lord withall.

div.stage: Enter V Valasco, a friend or two armed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ansilva?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Some body calls me, who is it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is I Valasco

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What comes he backe for? I hope the poyson does
Not worke already, where have you dispos'd her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dispos'd whom?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My Lady Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let me alone to dispose her, prethee where's the light?
Shew us the way.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What way?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The way to her chamber? come, I know what
You are sicke of, here each minute is an age till
I possesse Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: This is pretty, I hope my lady is well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My Lady Berinthia sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe you mocke me?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I mocke you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall grow angry, lead me to
Berinthias chamber, or—

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why sir, were not you here even now, and hurried
Her away, I have your gold well fare all good tokens;
I have perform'd my duty already sir, and you had my
Lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am abus'd you are a cunning Devill, I heare and had
Berinthia, tell me, or with this pistoll, I will soone
Reward thy treachery, where Berinthia?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Oh I beseech you doe not fright me so, if you were
Not here even now, here was another that call'd
Himselfe Valasco, to whom I gave accesse, and
He has carried her away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Am I awake? or doe I dreame this horrour:
Where am I? who does know me, are you friends
Of Don Valasco?
Doe you doubt us sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doubt my selfe, who am I
Our noble friend Valasco,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tis so, I am Valasco, all the Furies
Circle me round, oh teach me to be mad,
I am abus'd, insufferably tormented,
My very soule is whipt, it had beene safer
For Catalina to have plaid with Serpents.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Thou talkest of wonders, where is Valasco?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He was here even now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who nam'd Valasco?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Twas I, Catalina, here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Could you picke none out of the stocke of man
To mocke but me, so basely?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Valasco be your selfe, resume your vertue.
My thoughts are cleare from your abuse, it is
No time to vent our passions, fruitlesse rages,
Some hath abus'd us both, but a revenge
As swift as lightning shall pursue their flight:
Oh I could feare my braines, as you respect
Your honoures safety, or Berinthias love;
Haste to your lodging, which being nere our house,
You shall be sent for; seeme to be rais'd up,
Let us alone to make a noise at home,
Fearefull as thunder; try the event, this cannot
Doe any hurt, you Ansilva shall
With clamors wake the houshold cunningly,
While I prepare my selfe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will suspend awhile.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, theeves, villaines, murder my Lady:
Helpe oh my Lord, my Lady, murder theeves helpe.

div.stage: Enter Sebastiano in his first with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What fearefull cry is this, where are you?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Here oh I am almost kil'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ansilva where art hurt?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: All over sir, my Lady Berinthia is carried away
By Ruffians, that broke into her chamber, alas
Sees gone.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Whether? which way?
My sister Berinthia is violently tane out of her
Chamber, and heres Ansilva hurt, see looke about,
Berinthia sister.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: How Berin. gone? call up the servants,
Ansilva, how wast?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Alas Madam, I have not my senses about me, I am so
Frighted, vizards, and swords, and pistols, but my
Lady Berinthia was quickly seiz'd upon, shees gone.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What villaines durst attempt it?
sp.stage: Enter Count Monte de nigro with a torch.
sp.l: I feare Valasco guilty of this rape.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Runne one to his lodging presently, it will appeare
I know he lov'd her, oh my Lord, my sister Berinthias lost,

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How? foote my physicke begins to worke, ile come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Wheres Diego? he is missing, runne one to his chamber, heres Valasco.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is apparant sir, Valascoes noble.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Berinthias stolne away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Her Chamber broken ope, and shee tane thence this night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Confusion stay the theese.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: So, so, as you were saying, Berinthia was stolne away by some body, and—

sp.speaker: I. Ser.
sp.l: Diego is not in his chamber.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Didst breake ope the doore?

sp.speaker: I. Ser.
sp.l: I did, and found all empty.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: How, Diego gone? thats strange, oh it workers againe, Ile come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I doe suspect—
This some plot of Antonio,
Diego, a subtle villaine,
Confirmes himselfe an instrument by this absence;
What thinkest Ansilva?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Indeed I heard some of them name Antonio.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Seb.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Tis true upon my soule, oh false Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Vnworthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let none have the honour to revenge, but I the wrongd
Valasco, let me beg it sir.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Antonio, boy up before the day,
Vpon my blessing I command thee post
To Eluas Castle, summon that false man
To quit his shamefull action, bid him returne
Thy sister backe, whose honour will be lost
For ever in't, if he shall dare deny her,
Double thy Fathers spirit, call him to
A strickt account, and with thy sword enforce him,
Oh I could leape out of my age me thinkes,
And combat him my selfe: be thine the glory,
This staine will never wash off, I feele it settle
On all our blood, away, my curse pursue
This disobedience.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I had an interrest in Berinthia,
Why have not I commission, I have a sword,
Thirsteth to be acquainted with his veines;
It is too meane a satisfaction
To have her rendred, on his heart Ide write
A most just vengence.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir she is my sister, I have a sword dares tent
A wound as farre as any; spare your vallour

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I have a tricke to be rid of this foole, my Lord
Doe you accompany my brother, you
I know are valiant.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Any whither, Ile make me ready presently.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My most unhappy sister.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Oh I could surfet, I am confident
Antonio hath her, tis revenge beyond
My expectation, to close up the eyes
Of his Berinthia, dying in his armes,
Poyson'd maturely, mischiefe I shall prove
Thy constant friend, let weakenesse vertue love.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena I.
div.stage: Enter Antonio, Berinthia, Castabella, Villandras, Sforza, Diego.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: THe welcom'st guest that ever Eluas had
Sister, Villandras yare not sensible what treasure
You possesse, I have no loves, I would not here divide.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, yare as welcome here, as are my mother was.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: And you are here as safe, as if you had an army for your Guard.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Safe armies, and guard; Berinthia ya're a Lady,
But I meane not to court you: guard ●notha, here's
A Toledo, and an old arme, tough bones and sinewes,
Able to cut off as stout a head as wags upon a shoulder,
Thart Antonios guest, welcome by the old bones
Of his Father, th'ast a wall of brasse about thee
My young Daffodill.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Nor thinke my noble cozen meaneth you any dishonour here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dishonour, it is a language I never understood, yet
Throw off your feares Berinthia, yare ith' power
Of him that dares not thinke
The least dishonour to you.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: True by this busse jerkin, that hath look'd ith face of an Army, and he lies like a termagant, denies it, Antonio is Lord of the Castle, but ile command fire to the gunnes, upon any Renegado that confronts us, set thy heart at rest my gilloflower, we are all friends I warrant thee, and hees a Turke that does not honour thee from the haire of thy head, to thy pettitoes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come be not sad.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Put on fresh blood, yare not cheerefull, how doe you?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know not how, nor what to answer you,
Your loves I cannot be ungratefull to,
Yare my best friends I thinke, but yet I know not
With what consent you brought my body hither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you be ignorant what plot was laid
To take your faire life from you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: If all be not a dreame, I doe remember
Your servant Diego told me wenders, and
I owe you for my preservation, but—

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: Shoote not at Buts, Cupids an archer, here a faire marke, a f fooles bolts soone shot, my names Sforza still, my double Daisie.

sp.speaker: Cast
sp.p: It is your happinesse you have escaped the malice of your sister.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: And it is worth
A noble gratitude to have been quit,
By such an honourer as Antonio is
Of faire Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Oh but my Father, under whose displeasure I ever sinke,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are secure

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As the poore Deere that being pursuid, for safety
Gets up a rocke that over hangs the Sea,
Where all that she can see, is her destruction,
Before the waves, behinde her enemies
Promise her certaine ruine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Faine not your selfe so haplesse my Berinthia,
Raise your dejected thoughts, be merry, come,
Thinke I am your Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is not wisdome
To let our passed fortune, trouble us,
Since were they bad the memorie is sweete,
That we have past them, looke before you Lady,
The future most concerneth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You have awak'd me, Antonio pardon,
Vpon whose honour I dare trust my selfe,
I am resolv'd if you dare keepe me here,
T'expect some happier issue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dare keepe thee here? with thy consent, I dare
Deny thy Father, by this sword I dare,
And all the world.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: Dare, what giant of vallour dates hinder us, from daring to slit the weasands of them that dare say, wee dare not doe any thing, that is to be dared under the poles, I am old Sforza, that in my dayes have scoured rogues faces with hot bals, made em cut crosse capers, and sent them away with a powder, I have a company of roring buls upon the wals, shall spit fire in the faces of any ragamuffian that dares say, we dare not fight pell mell, and still my name is Sforza.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Sir your noble friend don Sebastionc is at the castle gate

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your brother Lady, and my honoured friend,
Why doe the gates not spread themselves, to open
At his arrivall Sforza, tis Berinthiaes brother,
Sebastiano the example of all worth
And friendship, is come after his sweete sister,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Alas I feare.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be not such a coward Lady, he cannot come
Without all goodnesse waiting on him, Sforza,
Sforza I say, what pretious time we lose,
Sebastiano, I almost lose my selfe
In joy to meete him, breake the iron barre
And give him entrance.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
