sp.l: Ile breake the wals downe, if the gates be too little.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I much desire to see him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sister, now hees come, he did promise me
But a short absence, he of all the world
I would call brother, Castabella more
Then for his sisters love, oh hees a man
Made up of merit, my Berinthia
Throw off all cloudes, Sebastianoes come.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sent by my Father to—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What, to see thee? he shall see thee hēre.
Respected like thy selfe, Berinthia,
Attended with Antonio, begirt with armies of thy servants
Oh my friend.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Tis yet in question sir, and will not be
So easily proved.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: No sir, weele make you prove your selfe our friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What face have you put on? am I awake?
Or doe I dreame Sebastiano frownes.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio I come not now to Complement,
While you were noble, I was not least of them
You cald your friends, but you are guilty of
An action that destroyes that name.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Bones a your Father, does he come to swagger,
My name is Sforza then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more,
I guiltie of an action so dishonourable
Has made me unworthy of your friendship;
Come y'are not in earnest, tis enough I know
My se'fe Antonio.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Adde to him ungratefull.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Twas a foule breath delivered it, and wert any
But Sebastiano, he should feele the weight
Of such a falshood.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sister you must along with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now by my Fathers soule, he that takes her hence
Vnlesse she give consent, treads on his grave,
Sebastiano, y'are unnoble then,
Tis I that said it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: So it seemes.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio, for here I throw of all
The ties of love, I come to fetch a sister,
Dishonourably taken from her father;
Or with my sword to force thee render her:
Now if thou beest a Souldier redeliver,
Or keepe her with the danger of thy person,
Thou canst not be my brother, till we first
Be allied in blood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Promise me the hearing,
And that have any satisfaction,
Becomes my fame.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: So, so, he will submit himselfe, it will be our honor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Were in your power, would you not account it
A pretious victory, in your sisters cause,
To dye your sword with any blood of him,
Sav'd both her life and honour?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I were ungratefull.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You have told your selfe, and I have argumēnt to prove this.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Why would you have me thinke, my sister owes to you such preservation?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh Sebastiano,
Thou dost not thinke what devill lies at home
Within a sisters bosome, Catalina,
(I know not with what worst of envy) laid
Force to this goodly building, and through poyson
Had rob'd the earth of more then all the world,
Her vertue.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You must not beate my resolution off
With these inventions sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be not cozend,
With your credulity, for my blood, I value it
Beneath my honour, and I dare by goodnesse,
In such a quarrell kill thee: but heare all,
And then you shall have fighting your heart full.
Valasco was the man, appointed by
That goodly sister to steale Berinthia,
And Lord himselfe of this possession,
Just at that time; but heare and tremble at it,
Shee by a cunning poyson should have breath'd
Her soule into his armes, within two houres,
And so Valasco should have borne the shame
Of theft and murther; how doe you like this sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You amaze me sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tis true by honours selfe, heare it confirm'd,
And when you will, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Pitty such valour should be imployd,
Vpon no better cause, they will enforme him.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Harke you sir, dee thinke this is true?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I dare maintaine it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thats another matter, why then the case is
Altered, what should we doe fighting, and lose
Our lives to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Sf.
sp.l: It seemes you are his second.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I am Count de Monte Nigro.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: And my names Sforza sir, you were not best to come here to brave us, unlesse you have more legges and armes at home, I have a saza shall picke holes in your doublet, and firke your shankes, my gallimaufry.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I cannot but beleeve it, oh Berinthia,
I am wounded ere I fight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Holds your resolve yet constant? if you have
Better opinion of your sword, then truth,
I am bound to answer, but I would I had
Such an advantage gainst another man,
As the justice of my cause, all vallour fights
But with a sayle against it.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Take a time to informe your father sir, my noble
Cozen is to be found here constant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: But will you backe with me then?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Excuse me brother, I shall fall too soone
Vpon my sisters malice, whose foule guilt
Will make me expect more certaine ruine,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now Sebestiano
Puts on his judgement, and assumes his noblenesse,
Whilst he loves equity.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And shall I carry shame
To Villarezoes house, neglect of father,
Whose precepts bindes me to returne with her,
Or leave my life at Eluas, I must on,
I have heard you to no purpose, shall Berinthia
Backe to Avero.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir she must not yet, tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Choose thee a second then, this Count and I
Meane to leave honor here.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Honour me sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tis done, Sebastiano shall report
Antonio just and noble, Sforza sweare
Vpon my Sword, oh doe not hinder me
If victory crowne Sebastianoes arme.
I charge thee by thy honesty restore
This Lady to him, on whose lip I seale
My unstain'd faith.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Vmh, tis a rare physitian, my spirit is abated.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And wilt thou be dishonourd?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Oh doe not wrong the Gentleman, beleeve it
Dishonour nere dwelt here, and he hath made
A most religious vow, not in a thought
To staine my innocence, he does not force me
Remember, what a noble friend, you make
A most just enemy, he sav'd my life,
Be not a murtherer, take yet a time,
Runne not your selfe in danger for a cause
Carries so little justice.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Faith sir, if you please take a time to thinke on't, a month or two or three, they shall not say but wee are honorable.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You gave him to my heart a Gentleman, Seb whisp.
Compleate with goodnesse, will you rob the world
And me at once, alas I love him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Never man fought with a lesser heart, the conquest
Will be but many deathes, he is her brother,
My friend, this poore girles joy.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: With all my heart, Ile post to Avero presently.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let it be so Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Alas pore Castabella, what a conflict
seest thou within thee, their fight woundeth thee,
And I must die, who ere hath victory:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then friend againe, and as Sebastiano,
I bid him welcome, and who loves Antonio
Must speake that language.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Enough, not a Masty upon the Castle wall,
But shall barke too, I congratulate thee, if thou
Beelest friend to the Castle of Eluas, and still my name
Is Sforza.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well said my brave Adelautado, come Sebastiano,
And my Birinthia by to morrow we shall know
The truth of our felicity.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What are the Nobles more than common men
When all their honour cannot free them from
Shame and abuse; as greatnesse were a marke
Stucke by them but to give direction
For men to shoote indignities upon them?
Are we call'd Lords of riches we possesse,
And can defend them from the ravishing hand
Of strangers, when our children are not safe
From theeves and robbers, none of us can challenge
Such right to wealth and fortunes of the world,
Being things without us; but our children are
Essentiall to us, and participate
Of what we are: part of our very nature,
Our selves but cast into a younger mold,
And can we promise, but so weake assurance
Of so neere treasures. O Villarezo shall
Thy age be trampled on, no, it shall not,
I will be knowne a father, Portugall
Shall not report this infamy unreveng'd,
It will be a barre in Vilarezoes armes
Past all posterity;
Come Catalina, thou wilt stay with me,
Prepare to welcome home Sebastiano,
Whom I expect with honour, and that baggage
Ambitious girle Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Alas sir; censure not her too soone,
Till she appeare are guilty.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Heres thy vertue still,
To excuse her Catalina, no beleeve it,
Shes naught, past hope, I have an eye can see
Into her very heart, thou art too innocent.
Valasco welcome too, Berinthia
Is not come home yet, but we shall seen her
Brought backe with shame; and ist not justice ha?
What can be shame enough?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your daughter sir?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: My daughter? doe not call her so, she has not
True blood of Vilarezo in her veines;
She makes her selfe a bastard, and deserves
To be cut off like a disordered branch,
Disgracing the faire tree she springeth from.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Lay not so great a bourthen on Berinthia,
Her nature knowes not to degenerate;
Vpon my life she was not yeelding, to
The injurious action; if Antonio
Have plaied the theefe, let your revenge fall there,
Which were I trusted with, although I doubt not
Sebastianoes fury; he should feele it
More heavy than his Castle, what can be
Too just for such a sinne?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Right, right Valasco, I doe love thee fort,
Tis so, and thou shalt see I have a sence
Worthy my birth and person.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'T will become you; but I marvell we hearē nothing
Of their successe at Eluas. by this time
I would have sent Antonio to warme
His fathers ashes, doe you not thinke sir?
Sebastiano will not be remisse,
A gentle nature is abus'd with tales,
Which they know how to colour; heres the Count.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: How, the Count? I sent him thither to be rid on him;
The foole has better fortune than I wisht him,
But now I shall heare that which will more comfort me,
My sisters death most certainely.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: My Lord, I have rid hard, read there, your sonne
And daughter is well.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Ha, well?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: How does my sister?

sp.speaker: Mount,
sp.l: In good health, she has commendations to you
In that letter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And is Antonio living?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Yes, and remembers his service to you,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Has he then yeelded up Berinthia?

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: He will yeeld up his ghost first, I know not we were
Going to flesh baste one another, I am sure but the
Matter of fellony hangs still, who will cut it downe;
I know not, Madam theres notable matter against you.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Vpon my honor there is, be not angry with me,
No lesse than theft and murder, that letter is charg'd
Withall, but you'le cleare all I make no question, they Talke of poysoning.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Am I betray'd?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Well, I smell, I smell.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: What do you smell?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: It was but a tricke of theirs to save their lives,
For we were bent to kill all that came against us.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Catalina reade here, Valasco, both of you,
And let me reade your faces, ha? they wonder.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Howe's this, I steale Berinthia?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I poyson my sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This doth amaze me.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Father, this letter sayes I would have poysoned my poore sister, innocence defend me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: It will, it shall, come Jacquit you both,
They must not thus foole me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Madam I thought as much, my minde gave me, it
Was a lye, yes, you looke like a poysoner, as much
As I looke like a Hobby-horse.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Was ever honest love so abused, have I
So poore reward for my affection.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Madam I know not how the poyson came in, but I
Feare some have betraied our plot.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: And how came you off my noble Count.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As you see without any wounds, but much against
My will I was but one, Sebastiano, that was the
Principall, tooke a demurre upon their allegation:
It seemes, and so the matter is rak'd up in the Embers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To make a greater fire, were you so cold
To credit his excuse, Antonio,
I should not have beene so frozen,
As you love honor and revenge, give me
Some interest now, and if I doe not
Shew my selfe faithfull, let Valasco have
No name within your memory, let me begge,
To be your Proxie sir, pitty such blood,
As yours should be ignobly cast away;
Maddam speake for me.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: No, J had rather lost this foole.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And you can get their consents.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: You cannot sir in honour now goe backe.
J shall not thinke you love me, if my father
Point you such noble service to refuse it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: You heare what she sayes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Count Monte nigro.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am all fire with rage.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Valasco, you may accompany the Count,
There may be imployment of your valour too;
Tell me at your returne, whether my sonne
May prove a souldier, heres new warrant for
Antonioes death, if there be coldnesse urge it,
Tis my desire, ile study a better service.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Away then both, no complement, I wish you either
Had a Pegasus, be happy, my old bloud boyles, this
Must my peace secure, such sores as these must
Have a desperate cure.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This honor Madam of your selfe and brother,
Make me unhappy, when I remember, what
I came for, not to feast thus but to fight.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Pitty true friendship should thus suffer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Musicke.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some conceit of Sforza the old Captaine,
Lets entertaine it, some souldiers device,
A maske of Souldiers.
Godamercy Sforza.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: To your stations now my brave brats of Millitary
Discipline, enough, Sforza honours you, looke to your
Charge Bullies, and be ready upon all occasions,
My invincible dub a dub knights of the Castle,
Qui vala.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We must speake with Don Sebastiano.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Must? Th'art a Mushrumpe, must, in the Castle of Eluas,
Monte nigro gives a letter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Friends; Sforza.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, courting Ladies, by this time 'twas expected
You would have courted fame sir, and woed her to you;
You shall know me better.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I doubt you'le never be better, you shall now owe me
More than you shall account for.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Or else my curse, that word cries out for death.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My feates perplexe me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Madam I doe wonder
You can forget your honour, and reflect
On such unworthinesse, wherein hath Valasco
Shewed you lesse merit.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sir it becomes not me
To weigh your worths, nor would I learne of you
How to preserve my honour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sister.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Villandras.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Then J must take my leave, for I am sent for,
I am sorry for your fate, Madam I am exepected
By a father your vertue hath made me yours.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Oh admirable phisitian!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sforza, there is no remedie, but by all honour doe it,
Sister, I am to waite on him, oh my poore girle
Berinthia, my soule be with thee, for a
Little time excuse my absence.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: You may walke sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Antonio I must but now looke on, you were
Best take a course not to out live him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sebastiano, I know not with what soule
I draw my sword against thee

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio I am driven in a storme
To split my selfe on thee, if not, any curse—
We must on sir.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Rare man of art Sharkino.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Guard thee Count.

div.stage: Enter Sfor. Val. and Ladies above.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Treacherous Sforza, hast thou brought us hither, to be stroke dead?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Hold Gentlemen, give me audience.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What's the matter my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: My fit is on me, tis so, I had forgot my selfe,
This is my ague day.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Yes a sextile ague, looke you, doe you not see me shake, admirable Doctor, it will be as much as my life is worth if I should fight a stroke.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hell on such basenesse, weele engage no more;
Let our swords try it out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sebastiano hold, thart not so ill be friended,
Exchange a person, ile leape the battlement.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: With all my heart, I am sorry it happens so vunfortvnately, oh rare phisitian!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Good cozen grant it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What saies Sebastiano.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I conjure you by all honour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is granted;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: He shall nor goe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Meete him my Lord, you will become his place of a
Spectator best.

sp.speaker: Ber
sp.l: Sebastiano brother.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Antonio, here me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Guard thee Valasco then.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O brother spare him for my sake.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sebastiano every wound thou givest him,
Drawes blood from me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sebastiano, remember hees thy friend.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Antonio tis my brother, with whose blood
Thou dyest thy sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When thou liv'st againe shalt be more honorable
Sebastiano doe you observe the advantage,
Yet thinke upon't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is not in my power. I value not the odds.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hold, Antonio, is this thy love to me, it is not noble.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So thy death makes the scale even.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Antonio hold, Berinthia dyes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sebastiano, Castabella sinkes for sorrow, murder, helpe
I will leape downe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where art Berinthia, let me breath my last upon thy lip, make haste, least I die else.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Antonio before thou dyest cut off my hand, art wounded mortally?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To die by thee is more then death, Sforza be honest,
But love thy sister for me, I me past hope,
Thou hast undone another in my death.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Antonio stay oh cruell brother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Berinthia thy lip farewell, and friend, and all the world.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: The gate is open, I am sworne to render.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hees not dead, his lips are warme, have you no balsome, a Surgeon; dead, some charitable hand send my soule after him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It will be easie to die,
All life is but a walke in misery.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: MY friend, my noble friend, that had deserved
Most honorably from me, by this hand
Divorc'd from life, and yet I have the use ont,
Haplesle Sebastiano; oh Berinthia,
Let me for ever lose the name of Brother,
Wilt thou not curse my memory, give me up
To thy just hate a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Ha, this must not be Sebastiano,
I shall be angry if you throw not off
This mellancholly, it does ill become you,
Doe you repent your duty, were the action
Againe presented to be done by thee:
And being done, againe should challenge from thee
A new performance, thou wouldst shew no blood
Of Vilarezoes, if thou didst not runne
To act it, though all horror, death and vengeance
Dog'd thee at thy heeles; come I am thy Father,
Value my blessing, and for other peace
Ile to the King, let me no more see thee cloudy.

div.stage: Enter Diego, Castabella like a page.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: That was his Father.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No more, farewell, be all silence.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hees newly gone that way, mayst soone ore take him

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My businesse points at you sir.

sp.speaker: Seb,
sp.p: At me, what newes? thou hast a face of horrour, more welcome speake it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: If your name be Don Sebastiano, sir
I have a token from a friend.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I have no friend alive boy, carry it backe,
Tis not to me, I've not another friend
In all the world.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He that hath sent you sir this gift, did love you,
Youle say your selfe he did.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ha, name him prethee.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The friend I came from was Antonio.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou lyest, and thart a villane, who hath sent thee
To tempt Sebastianoes soule to act on thee
Another death, for thus afrighting me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeede I doe not mocke, nor come to afright you
Heaven knowes my heart, I know Antonioes dead,
But twas a gift he in his life design'd
To you, and I have brought it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou dost not promise cozenage, what gift is it?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is my selfe sir, while Antonio liv'd, I was his boy,
But never did boy loose so kinde a Master, in his life he
Promised he would bestow me, so much was his love
To my poore merit, on his dearest friend,
And nam'd you sir, if heaven should point out
To overlive him, for he knew you would
Love me the better for his sake, indeed
I will be very honest to you, and
Refuse no service to procure your love
and good opinion to me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Can it be
Thou wert his boy, oh thou shouldst hate me then,
Th'art false, I dare not trust thee, unto him
Thou shewest thee now unfaithfull to accept
Of me, I kild him thy Master, twas a friend
he could commit thee to, I onely was,
Of all the stocke of men his enemy,
His cruellest enemy.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeede I am sure it was, he spoke all truth,
And had he liv'd to have made his will, I know
He had bequeathed me as a legacy
To be your boy; alas I am willing sir
To obey him in it, had he laid on me
Command, to have mingled with his sacred dust,
My unprofitable blood, it should have beene
A most glad sacrifice, and 'thad beene honour
To have done him such a duty sir, I know
You did not kill him with a heart of mallice,
But in contention with your very soule
To part with him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: All is as true as Oracle by heaven,
Dost thou beleeve so?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeede I doe.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yet be not rash;
Tis no advantage to belong to me,
I have no power nor greatnesse in the Court,
To raise thee to a fortune, worthy of
So much observance as I shall expect
when thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: All the ambition of my thoughts shall be
To doe my dutie sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Besides, I shall afflict thy tendernesse
With sollitude and passion, for I am
Onely in love with sorrow, never merry,
Weare out the day in telling of sad tales,
Delight in sighes and teares; sometimes I walke
To a Wood or River purposely to challenge
The bouldest Eccho, to send backe my groanes
Ith' height I breake e'm, come I shall undoe thee.

sp.speaker: Cast,
sp.l: Sir, I shall be most happy to beare part
In any of your sorrowes, I nere had
So hard a heart but I could shed a teare
To beare my Master company.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I will not leave thee if thou'lt dwell with me
For wealth of Indies, be my loved boy,
Come in with me, thus Ile begin to do
Some recompence for dead Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: So I will dare my fortune to be cruell,
And like a mountanous peece of earth that suckes
The balls of hot Artillery, I will stand
And weary all the gunshot; oh my soule
Thou hast beene too long icy Alpes of snow;
Have buried my whole nature, it shall now
Turne Element of fire, and fill the ayre
With bearded Comets, threatning death and horrour
For my wrong'd innocence, contemn'd, disgrac'd,
Nay murther'd, for with Antonio
My breath expired, and I but borrow this
To court revenge for justice, if there be
Those furies which doe waite on desperate men,
As some have thought, and guide their hands to mischiefe.
Come from the wombe of night, assist a maide
Ambitious to be made a monster like you;
I will not dread your shapes, I am dispos'd
To be at friendship with you, and want nought
But your blacke aide to seale it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: First ile locke up thy
Tongue, and tell thee my honorable meaning, so,
To tell you the truth, it is a love-powder, J had it of the
Brave Doctor, which I would have thee to suger
The Ladies cup withall, for my sake wo't do't:
And if I marry her shat find me a noble
Master, and thou shalt be my chiefe Gentlewoman
In Ordinary; keepe thy body loose, and thou shalt
Want no gowne I warrant thee; wo't do't.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My Lord, I thinke my Lady is much taken with your
worth already, so that this will be superfluous,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I Nay think she has cause enough, but I have a great
Mind to make an end on't, to tell you true, there are
Halfe a dozen about mee, but I had rather she should have
Me than an other; and my blood is growne so boysterous
For my body, thats another thing; so that if thou wilt
Doe it Ansilva, thou wilt doe thy Lady good service,
And live in the favour of Count de Monte Nigro;
I will make thy children kinne to me, if thou wo't
Do't.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am your honours handmaid, but—

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Heres a Diamond, prethee weare it, be not modest.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: 'Tis done my Lord, urge it no further.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: But be secret too for my honors sake, we great men
Doe not love to have our actions laid open to the
Broad face of the world, Ile get thee with child,
And marry thee to a Knight, my brave Ansilva, take
The first opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Jf there be any vertue in the powder, prepare to
Meete your wishes my noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Thy Count de monte nigro expect to be a Lady.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ansilva.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nay you neede not hide it, I heard the conference,
And know the vertue of the powder, let me see it
Or ile discover all.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, here take it againe, ile not prevent
My sisters happinesse and the Counts desire,
I am no Tell-tale good Ansilva giv't her,
And heavens succeede the operation,
I begge on my knee; feare not Ansilva,
I am all silence.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Indeede Madam, then shee shall have it presently.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir, if the opportunity I use
To comfort you be held a fault, and that
I keepe not distance of a servant, lay it
Vpon my love; indeede if it be an errour
It springs out of my duty.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Prethee boy be patient;
The more I strive to throw off the remembrance
Of dead Antonio, love still rubbes the wounds
To make them bleede afresh.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Alas they are past,
Binde up your owne for honours sake,
And shew love to your selfe, pray do not lose your reason,
To make your griefe so fruitlesse; I have procur'd
Some musicke sir to quiet those sad thoughts,
That makes such warre within you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Alas good boy, it will but adde more weights
Of dulnesse on me, I am stung with worse
Than the Tarantula, to be cur'd with musicke
'T has the exactest unity, but it cannot,
Accord my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sir this your couch
Seemes to invite so small repose;
Oh I beseech you taste it, ile begge
A little leave to sing;
Sweete sleepe charme his sad sences, and gentle
Thoughts let fall your flowing numbers, here round
About hover caelestiall Angels with your wings
That none offend his quiet, sleepe begins
To cast his nets o're me too, ile obey,
And dreame on him, that dreames not what I am.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nature doth wrestle with me, but revenge
Doth arme my love against it, justice is
Above all tie of blood Sebastiano
Thou art the first shalt tell Antonioes ghost
How much I lov'd him.

div.stage: She stabbes him upon his couch; Castab. rises and runnes in.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Oh stay thy hand Berinthia? no
Th'ast don't, I wish thee heavens forgivenesse, I cannot
Tarry to heare thy reasons, at many doores,
My life runnes out, and yet Berinthia
Doth in her name give me more wounds then these,
Antonio, oh Antonio, we shall now
Be friendes againe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Hees dead, and yet I live, but not to fall
Lesse then a constellation, more flames must
Make up the fire that Berinthia
And her revenge, must bathe in.

div.stage: Enter Catalina poysoned, pulling Ansilva by the haire.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sebastiano, sister.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: murder.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Theres wild-fire in my bowells, sure I am poysoned;
Oh Berinthia.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Helpe me to teare Ansilva, I am poysoned by
The Count and this fury.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Doe you laugh hereat.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes queene of hell to see thee
Sinke in the glory of thy hope for blisse:
But art sure th' art poysoned, ha?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nay I have my part on't, I did but sip, and my belly
Swells too; call you this love-powder, Count Monte
Nigro hath poysoned us both.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Y'are a paire of witches, and because
Ile keepe your potion working, know y'are both
Poyson'd by me, by me Berinthia,
Being thus tormented with my wrongs,
I arm'd my selfe with all provision
For my revenge, and had in readinesse
That faithfull poyson which ith' opportunity
I put upon Ansilva for the exchange
Of the amorous powder; oh fooles, my soule
Ravish thy selfe with laughter, politsion
My eldest divell sister, does the heate
Offend your stomacke, troth charity, a little charitie
Th'onely Antidote, thats cold enough:
Looke heres Sebastiano;
Now horrour strike thy soule, to whose fearelesse heart
I sent this punyard, for Antonioes death;
And if that peece of thy damnation
Ansilva had not don't, I meant to have writ
Revenge with the same point upon thy breast;
But I doe surfeit in this brave prevention:
Sleepe, sleepe Antonioes ashes, and now ope
Thou marbell chest to take Berinthia
To mingle with his dust.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I have not so much heart as to curse, must I die?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Here my Lord, alas hees dead, my Sebastiano

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Catalina.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I am poyson'd.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Ha, Defend good heaven, by whom.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am poysoned too.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Racke not my soule amazement, tis a dreame sure.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Your Love-powder hath poysoned us both.

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: What will become of me now, I would I were hang'd
To be out of my paine, by this flesh, as I am a Count.
I bought it of the Doctor for good love-powder;
But Madam I hope you are not poysoned in earnest.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: The devill on your fooleship, oh I must walke
The darke foggy way that spits fire and brimstone,
No physicke to restore me? send for Sharkino, a cooler
A cooler, there's a Smiths forge in my belly, and the
Devill blowes the Bellowes, Snow-water, Berinthia
Has poysoned me, sinke by mine owne engine;
I must hence, hence, farewell, will you let me die so?
Confusion, torment, death, hell.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I am glad with all my heart that Berinthia has
Poysoned her, yet—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Oh it becomes thee bravely, heare me sir.
Antonioes death and my dishonours now
Have just revenge; I stabb'd Sebastiano, poysoned my sister,
Oh but they made too soone a fury of me,
And split the patience, from whose dreadfull breach
Came these consuming fires, your passions fruitless;
My soule is reeling forth I know not whether;
Oh father my heart weepes teares, for you I dye, oh see
A maides revenge with her owne Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Ansilva, oh thou dull wretch, hell on thy cursed
Weakenesse, thou gavest me
The poyson, but I licke earth, hold, a gentleman
Vsher to support me, oh I am gone, the poyson
Now hath torne my heart in peeces, Moritur.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I am Planet strucke, a direfull Tragedy, and have
I no part in't: how doe you like it, ha? wast not
Done toth' life? they are my owne children; this was
My eldest girle, this Berinthia the Tragedian,
Whose love by me resisted, was mother of all this
Horror; and theres my boy too, that slew Antonio
Valiantly, and fell under his sisters rage, what
Art thou boy?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Ile tell you now I am no boy,
But haplesse Castabella, sister to
The slaine Antonio, I had hop'd to have
Some recompence by Sebastianoes love,
For whose sake in disguise I thus adventur'd
To purchase it, but death hath ravisht us,
And here I bury all my joyes on earth.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Sweet lady, heres Count de Monte nigro alive
To be your servant.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Hence dull greatnesse.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Were you a friend of Sebastiano then?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Ile give you testimony.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: No, I beleeve you, but thou canst not be my daughter;
Tis false, he lies that sayes Beriathia
Was author of their deathes, 'twas Villarezo,
A fathers wretched curiosity, dead, dead, dead.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: And I will leave the world too, for I meane
To spend the poore remainder of my dayes
In some Religious house, married to heaven,
And holy prayers for Sebastianoes soule,
And my lost brother.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Will you so?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I pray let Castabella have the honour
To enshrine his bones, and when my breath expires,
For sorrow promiseth I shall not live
To see more Sunnes, let me be buried by him
As neere as may be possible, that in death
Our dust may meete, oh my Sebastiano,
Thy wounds are mine.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Come I am arm'd, take up their bodies, Castabella you
Are not chiefe mourner here, he was my sonne,
Remember that, Berinthia first, she was the
Youngest, put her ith' pithole first, then Catalina;
Strow, strow flowers enough upon em, for they
Were maides; now Sebastiano, take him
Vp gently, he was all the sonnes I had; now
March, come you and I are twinnes in this dayes
Vnhappinesse, wee'le match together, follow close
Wee'le overtake em, softly, and as we go,
Wee'le dare our fortune for another woe.
